title: status (and rev-save) treatment of the path is "revolutionary": we need to unify
body:
This is largely a follow up to #3230 (the overall mixup of semantics) and complement to #3282 (treatment of relative paths, not the case of absolute path and `None` dataset). I found a peace of mind through us agreeing somewhat (in #3230) on the semantic that specifying a path to a datalad command, without dataset explicitly, switches the context of the operation to that dataset.  That is how I believe many, primarily old, commands still operate (`install`, `get`, `uninstall`, `drop`, `add/save`, ...).  But `status` assumes current dataset as the "context" of operation, and then fails whenever target path is outside:

```shell
$> datalad status /tmp/bmtemp/datalad_temp_bm_FQIGk4/testds10
[ERROR  ] dataset containing given paths is not underneath the reference dataset <Dataset path=/home/yoh/proj/datalad/datalad>: [] [status(/tmp/bmtemp/datalad_temp_bm_FQIGk4/testds10)] 
```
similarly (may be just because of use of `status` inside) for `rev-save`
```shell
$> datalad rev-save /tmp/bmtemp/datalad_temp_bm_FQIGk4/testds10 
[ERROR  ] dataset containing given paths is not underneath the reference dataset <Dataset path=/home/yoh/proj/datalad/datalad>: [] [status(/tmp/bmtemp/datalad_temp_bm_FQIGk4/testds10)] 
```

If we switch to such semantic it would become impossible to `install` a dataset or obtain (`get`) content without specifying on which dataset (i.e. providing `-d`) to operate.
